infodynamics.measures.discrete
Class ApparentTransferEntropyCalculator

java.lang.Object
  infodynamics.measures.discrete.InfoMeasureCalculator
      infodynamics.measures.discrete.ContextOfPastMeasureCalculator
          infodynamics.measures.discrete.ApparentTransferEntropyCalculator
All Implemented Interfaces:
ChannelCalculator
public class ApparentTransferEntropyCalculator
extends ContextOfPastMeasureCalculator
implements ChannelCalculator

Implements transfer entropy (see Schreiber, PRL, 2000) and local transfer entropy (see Lizier et al, PRE, 2008). We use the term apparent transfer entropy to mean that we compute the transfer that appears to come from a single source variable, without examining any other potential sources (see Lizier et al, PRE, 2008).

Specifically, this implements the transfer entropy for discrete-valued variables.

Usage:

  1. Construct: ApparentTransferEntropyCalculator(int, int)
  2. Initialise: initialise()
  3. Either:
    1. Continuous accumulation of observations then measurement; call:
      1. addObservations(int[], int[]) or related calls several times over - note: each method call adding observations can be viewed as updating the PDFs; they do not append the separate time series (this would be incorrect behaviour for the transfer entropy, since the start of one time series is not necessarily related to the end of the other).
      2. The compute relevant quantities, e.g. computeLocalFromPreviousObservations(int[], int[]) or computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
    2. or Standalone computation from a single set of observations; call e.g.: computeLocal(int[], int[]) or computeAverageLocal(int[][], int).>/li>

Author:
Joseph Lizier, email, www
See Also:
"Schreiber, Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000; download (for definition of transfer entropy)", "Lizier, Prokopenko and Zomaya, Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008; download (for definition of local transfer entropy and qualification of naming it as apparent transfer entropy)"

Constructor Detail

ApparentTransferEntropyCalculator

public ApparentTransferEntropyCalculator(int base,
                                         int history)
Create a new TE calculator for the given base and history length.

Parameters:
base - number of quantisation levels for each variable. E.g. binary variables are in base-2.
history - history length of the destination to condition on - this is k in Schreiber's notation.

addObservations

public void addObservations(int[] dest,
                            int[] source,
                            int startTime,
                            int endTime)
Add observations for a single source-destination pair of the multi-agent system to our estimates of the pdfs. This call is for time series not part of the same 2D array. Start and end time are the (inclusive) indices within which to add the observations. The start time is from the earliest of the k historical values of the destination (inclusive), the end time is the last destination time point to add in.

Parameters:
dest -
source -
startTime -
endTime -

addObservations

public void addObservations(int[][] states,
                            int j)
Add observations in to our estimates of the pdfs. This call suitable only for homogeneous agents, as all agents will contribute to single pdfs.

Parameters:
states - 1st index is time, 2nd index is agent number
j - - number of columns to compute transfer entropy across (i.e. src i-j, dest i: transfer is j cells to the right)

addObservations

public void addObservations(int[][][] states,
                            int h,
                            int j)
Add observations in to our estimates of the pdfs. This call suitable only for homogeneous agents, as all agents will contribute to single pdfs.

Parameters:
states - 1st index is time, 2nd and 3rd index give the 2D agent number
h - - number of rows to compute transfer entropy across
j - - number of columns to compute transfer entropy across (i.e. src (g-h,i-j), dest (g,i): transfer is h cells down, j cells to the right)

getPastCount

public int getPastCount(int pastVal)
Returns the count of observations of the past given state dest[n]^k. The past state is indicated by a discrete integer representing the joint variable of the k past states: (dest[n-k+1],dest[n-k+2],...,dest[n-1],dest[n]). The integer is computed as:
pastVal = dest[n-k+1] * base^(k-1) + dest[n-k+2] * base^(k-2) + ... + dest[n-1] * base + dest[n]

Parameters:
pastVal - joint state of the past of the destination dest[n]^k
Returns:
count of observations of the given past state

getPastProbability

public double getPastProbability(int pastVal)
Parameters:
pastVal - joint state of the past of the destination dest[n]^k
Returns:
probability of the given past state

getNextPastCount

public int getNextPastCount(int destVal,
                            int pastVal)
Returns the count of observations of the past given state dest[n]^k and next state dest[n+1].

Parameters:
destVal - next state of the destination dest[n+1]
pastVal - joint state of the past of the destination dest[n]^k
Returns:
count of observations of the given past state and next state
See Also:
for how the joint value representing the past is calculated.

computeSignificance

public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
Compute the significance of obtaining the given average TE from the given observations This is as per Chavez et. al., "Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals", Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128.

Specified by:
computeSignificance in interface ChannelCalculator
Parameters:
numPermutationsToCheck - number of new orderings of the source values to compare against
Returns:
